text: hi everyone whoo vamping fang tano here
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of the new dope
body record lifer these guys are a
baltimore rock band i believe they're on
their fourth full-length album they came
out with a cassette years ago
on watercolor records back in 2011 they
came out with their album nothing on
hoss records but in 2012 came their drag
city records debut album natural history
that year that year the album came out
it was one of my favorite rock records
of that year please give it a listen on
this record not only did i love the band
songs but i fell in love with their
sound and their style as well which
incorporates elements of noise rock post
hardcore a little bit of metal
irresistible grooves and bass lines even
though dope bodies music is incredibly
aggressive it's also incredibly funky
too especially on songs such as powder
and road dog
do what you want to do be what you want
to be
now not only is dope body on this record
and in their music in general fantastic
instrumentally but it is also the vocals
that kind of makes the band stand out
front man andrew laumann's wild shouts
and shrieks and caveman-like grunts
really bring the energy level of dope
bodies music up so high so with dope
body's last record being a total
powerhouse and the one prior to it
growing on me slowly with each passing
time i listened to it what is the band
gonna do
next well i think we got a little hint
of that when they dropped a single last
year for the song saturday there was
rougher production on these two songs
just wilder more chaotic performances
but aside from that there weren't really
any major defining characteristics about
these two new songs except for maybe
that they were less driven by the really
weird and quirky grooves that were all
over natural history which is a change
in direction that kind of makes sense
because i think the band did that sound
all the justice they possibly could on
natural history to me natural history is
very much dope body finishing something
that they started on nupping whereas
lifer feels like the band is beginning
something that is slightly newer for
them because not only are there elements
of noise rock and post hardcore on this
new album but there's also some
psychedelic rock in here too some
classic rock flavors as well post punk
and grunge which is pretty funny to
think because on dope bodies record
nupping there is a track titled the
shape of grunge to come some tracks do
have kind of a nirvana or like early
sound garden vibe to them so lifer is
not as tightly wound or as funky as
natural history but dope body finds
different ways to experiment namely with
very slow
strung out guitars and verses
vocals very loose playing and
performances very chaotic
so while there are a lot of verses on
this record that are kind of subdued
it's the choruses that are really heavy
and loud and brash abrasive and
climactic some of them are loaded with
psychedelic guitar solos some of them
have really brittle distorted swells of
guitar sound dope bodies mo on this
record really seems to be that loud soft
dynamic they're doing everything and
anything they can do to create the
greatest amount of contrast between part
a of the song and part b whether that be
a sonic contrast an emotional one a
stylistic one the band may be totally
just like off their rocker and out of
control for one second but then they'll
just tighten up and start just like a
well-oiled machine punching through
those riffs so that's kind of a
structural change for dope body another
change is there are songs on this record
that seem to get more intense as they
carry on you know really just escalating
in a sort of linear fashion tracks like
repo man as well as the seven minute
closing track here which i might add is
loaded with sort of noisy glitchy
synthesizers something i don't believe
the band has done before and adam's
vocal delivery has changed quite
significantly on some of these songs too
he's still a madman and and is willing
to show that side on numerous tracks
here but during these more toned down
versus he is legitimately
singing at first it may be kind of hard
to swallow and with tracks like new
sensation he kind of sounds like he's
just sort of around but i found
it easier to get into most of the
performances here after just a handful
of listens to these songs namely on
tracks like echo it's on songs like this
where adam's very pained moans and
whimpers where he's just kind of like
wandering around aimlessly it reminds me
a lot of honest honest from man man if
you've heard that band not only that but
this track also features some very slow
spacious kind of back woods guitars that
maybe have a bit of a southern rock vibe
to them but as soon as the chorus kicks
in the song just rockets off into these
spiraling guitar chords that send the
song spinning at a thousand rpm so while
there are some great tracks on here that
create that fantastic contrast between
some parts of the song and other parts
of the song there are also tracks here
that just straight up rock in the way
that you would expect a dope body song
to rock like the track toy which is
maybe as punk as it gets
on this record complete with lyrics
about wanting to be original and not
wanting to be a wannabe also the song's
rare air and day by day tracks that have
very very very abrasive lively choruses
but the verses have these kind of watery
milky bass lines that sound like they
would be very comfortable inside of like
a joy division song or like a bauhaus
song even as on the song day by day adam
is delivering vocals that feel like they
could be placed onto a fugazi record the
the ian makai side of a fugazi record
then there's the song hired gun which
features one of the most bad ass heavy
noisy guitar riffs of any dope body song
yet and for whatever reason the
melody that this riff plays
just eerily similar to that of the vocal
line on the rolling stone street
fighting man throughout this record
there are loads of subtle references to
numerous rock disciplines and they are
executed really well without watering
down dope bodies trademark personality
and just exuberant energy simply put i
think this is just another great record
from dope body i wish the production on
here was just a little bit cleaner
because i think the production quality
on natural history was was very very
ideal but still despite that very small
issue this is a very wild it's a brash
rock record with personality with
viscera with guts with
explosivity with songs that have
numerous parts to them lots of changes
lots of shifts the band shows that they
can write they can perform they could
play it loose they could play it tight
and they can switch from one to the
other at the drop of a hat i'm feeling a
decent to strong eight on this record
tran you're the best around
um position and um
if you've given this record a listen
what did you think did you love it did
you hate it why what do you think i
should review next and that's it anthony
fantano adope a body
forever
